title: Speeding up Go with custom allocators
Description: Speeding up a well-known benchmark (construction of binary trees) ~4x by optimizing memory allocations.

inline_content.Text: Description: Speeding up a well-known benchmark (construction of binary trees) ~4x by optimizing memory allocations.

inline_content.Text: : using a custom allocator I was able to speed up an allocation heavy program (

title: Allocation is expensive. It holds true for all languages. At the time of this writing, Go (version 1.0.3) doesn’t have a garbage collector that is as sophisticated as, say, garbage collector in JVM. There’s work being done to improve Go’s GC but today allocations in Go are not as cheap as they could be.

inline_content.Text: Allocation is expensive. It holds true for all languages. At the time of this writing, Go (version 1.0.3) doesn’t have a garbage collector that is as sophisticated as, say, garbage collector in JVM. There’s work being done to improve Go’s GC but today allocations in Go are not as cheap as they could be.

title: This can be seen in binary-trees benchmark which has almost no computation but millions of allocations of small objects. As a result, Java implementation is about 7x faster.

inline_content.Text: This can be seen in binary-trees benchmark which has almost no computation but millions of allocations of small objects. As a result, Java implementation is about 7x faster.

title: I was able to speed up Go code by about 4x by using a custom allocator.

inline_content.Text: I was able to speed up Go code by about 4x by using a custom allocator.

title: First, a correction. When I said that allocation is expensive, I over-simplified.

inline_content.Text: First, a correction. When I said that allocation is expensive, I over-simplified.

title: In garbage-collected languages allocation is actually very cheap. In a good allocator it’s just a single arithmetic operation to bump a pointer, which is orders of magnitude cheaper than even the best
malloc()
c
implementation.
Malloc()
c
has to maintain data structures to keep track of allocated memory so that
free()
c
can return it back to the OS.

inline_content.Text: In garbage-collected languages allocation is actually very cheap. In a good allocator it’s just a single arithmetic operation to bump a pointer, which is orders of magnitude cheaper than even the best
has to maintain data structures to keep track of allocated memory so that
can return it back to the OS.

title: More complicated reality is that it’s garbage collection phase that is expensive.

inline_content.Text: More complicated reality is that it’s garbage collection phase that is expensive.

title: Garbage collection (gc) is triggered every once in a while. It recursively scans all the allocated objects, starting from known roots and chasing pointers. It figures out which objects are not referenced by any other object and frees them (this is the “garbage” in garbage collection that has just been collected).

inline_content.Text: Garbage collection (gc) is triggered every once in a while. It recursively scans all the allocated objects, starting from known roots and chasing pointers. It figures out which objects are not referenced by any other object and frees them (this is the “garbage” in garbage collection that has just been collected).

title: There are 2 insights we get from knowing how garbage collection works internally:

inline_content.Text: There are 2 insights we get from knowing how garbage collection works internally:

title: the more objects there are, the more expensive garbage collection is

inline_content.Text: the more objects there are, the more expensive garbage collection is

title: the more pointers we need to chase, the more expensive gc is

inline_content.Text: the more pointers we need to chase, the more expensive gc is

title: Knowing what the problem is, we know what the solution should be:

inline_content.Text: Knowing what the problem is, we know what the solution should be:

title: allocate less objects (e.g. by allocating them in bulk or re-using previously allocated objects)

inline_content.Text: allocate less objects (e.g. by allocating them in bulk or re-using previously allocated objects)

title: As it happens, the majority of the 4x speedup I got in this particular benchmark came from not using pointers

inline_content.Text: As it happens, the majority of the 4x speedup I got in this particular benchmark came from not using pointers

title: Our implementation is a bit more sophisticated. In Go it’s easy to extend the array with
append()
c
but it involves memory copy. We avoid that by pre-allocating nodes in buckets and using an array of arrays for storage. The code is still relatively simple:

title: Another minor advantage if using integers instead of pointers in Node struct is that on 64-bit machines we use only 4 bytes for an int vs. 8 bytes for a pointer.

inline_content.Text: Another minor advantage if using integers instead of pointers in Node struct is that on 64-bit machines we use only 4 bytes for an int vs. 8 bytes for a pointer.

title: The biggest drawback is that we lost ability to free objects. Memory we’ve allocated will never be returned to the OS until the program exits.

inline_content.Text: The biggest drawback is that we lost ability to free objects. Memory we’ve allocated will never be returned to the OS until the program exits.

title: It’s not a problem in this case, since the tree only grows and the program ends when it’s done.

inline_content.Text: It’s not a problem in this case, since the tree only grows and the program ends when it’s done.

title: In different code this could be a much bigger issue. There are ways to free memory even with custom allocators but they require more complexity and evolve towards implementing a custom garbage collector at which point it might be better to go back to simple code and leave the work to built-in garbage collector.

inline_content.Text: In different code this could be a much bigger issue. There are ways to free memory even with custom allocators but they require more complexity and evolve towards implementing a custom garbage collector at which point it might be better to go back to simple code and leave the work to built-in garbage collector.

title: How come Java is so much faster?

inline_content.Text: How come Java is so much faster?

title: It’s a valid question: both Java and Go have garbage collectors, why is Java’s so much better on this benchmark?

inline_content.Text: It’s a valid question: both Java and Go have garbage collectors, why is Java’s so much better on this benchmark?

title: Java, unlike Go, uses generational garbage collector, which has 2 arenas: one for young (newly allocated) objects (called nursery) and one for old objects.

inline_content.Text: Java, unlike Go, uses generational garbage collector, which has 2 arenas: one for young (newly allocated) objects (called nursery) and one for old objects.

title: It has been observed that most objects die young. Generational garbage collector allocates objects in nursery. Most collections only collect objects in nursery. Objects that survived collections in nursery are moved to the second arena for old objects, which is collected at a much lower rate.

inline_content.Text: It has been observed that most objects die young. Generational garbage collector allocates objects in nursery. Most collections only collect objects in nursery. Objects that survived collections in nursery are moved to the second arena for old objects, which is collected at a much lower rate.

title: Go collector is a simpler mark-and-sweep collector which has to scan all allocated objects during every collection.

inline_content.Text: Go collector is a simpler mark-and-sweep collector which has to scan all allocated objects during every collection.

title: Generational garbage collectors have overhead because they have to copy objects in memory and update references between objects when that happens. On the other hand they can also compact memory, improving caching and they scan a smaller number of objects during each collection.

inline_content.Text: Generational garbage collectors have overhead because they have to copy objects in memory and update references between objects when that happens. On the other hand they can also compact memory, improving caching and they scan a smaller number of objects during each collection.

title: In this particular benchmark there are many Node objects and they never die, so they are promoted to rarely collected arena for old objects and each collection is cheaper because it only looks at a small number of recently allocated Node objects.

inline_content.Text: In this particular benchmark there are many Node objects and they never die, so they are promoted to rarely collected arena for old objects and each collection is cheaper because it only looks at a small number of recently allocated Node objects.

title: There’s hope for Go, though. The implementors are aware that garbage collector is not as good as it could be and there is an ongoing work on implementing a better one.

inline_content.Text: There’s hope for Go, though. The implementors are aware that garbage collector is not as good as it could be and there is an ongoing work on implementing a better one.

title: A win in C++ as well

malloc()\free()
c
are relatively slow functions.
